title: Will farmland values in the Seventh Federal Reserve District be higher in the first quarter of 2017 than they were in first quarter of 2016?
preds: Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Take a look at the inflation-adjusted values.  It appears that during times of high inflation, the adjusted values are higher than the nominal values.  We see the opposite when inflation is low.  Throughout the period of low inflation, the separation between the nominal values and the adjusted values has increased.  Just look at that gulf between adjusted values and nominal values.  I'm not certain what the inflection point (as seen by intersection, not by change in direction)  would look like and if we’d see a similar pattern as the buildup or instead see a crash.  It looks like the last intersection in 1981 is the basis for the index.  So, which values are appropriate to resolve this question or does it even matter?  Nominal or inflation-adjusted?  I’m assuming that PCEPI (personal consumption expenditures price index) is a measure of inflation, just as CPI.  All of this probably sounds like a lot of babbling. Which side that this question will resolve appears to be close yet on the basis of uncertainty and also on the details of the February 2017 AgLetter my guess is that land prices will either hold or decrease.

Been thinking about the value of heuristics or simple model vs. complex model.  Gerd Gigerenzer discusses this issue in the Behavioral Economics Guide 2016.  In the introductory article titled Taking Heuristics Seriously, he speaks of two sources of error:  bias and variance.  How do these sources of error impact a prediction?  To arrive at that question, Gigerenzer initially brings up the assumption of the accuracy-effort trade-off and how that trade-off might not apply in all cases.  In doing this, he compares situations of “risk” versus situations of “uncertainty”.  That trade-off does not necessarily apply in situations of “uncertainty” as opposed to situations of “risk”.  The bias-variance dilemma is the mathematical principle that assists in helping one understand that playoff.  Figure 2 of that article is a good visual depiction of his discussion. http://www.behavioraleconomics.com/BEGuide2016.pdf

Read the articles at these two links:
http://www.southeastfarmpress.com/corn/what-history-can-teach-us-about-today-s-farm-recession
https://ag.purdue.edu/commercialag/ageconomybarometer/producer-sentiment-backs-off-january-peak/ Probability of recession based on yield curve analysis:
https://www.newyorkfed.org/medialibrary/media/research/capital_markets/Prob_Rec.pdf
Prices have been declining for a while now.

In my experience. the safest bet for a big complex system is inertia and continuity. Farmland values for the seventh district have been declining for three years now, and while the rate of decline is slowing (1% in 2016 vs 3% in 2015 and 2014) the fundamental drivers of the decline haven't gone away. Namely, commodity prices are still depressed (although less so), and as the article below points out, farmers are still worrying a lot about cost cutting, not typically a sign that things are improving. Indeed, in his most recent letter (second link) David Oppedahl, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago's senior business economist, noted that commodity prices are still below their peak while input prices "have not fallen as much". Economist speak for getting squeezed at both ends.  http://www.iowafarmertoday.com/news/regional/farmers-lenders-keep-focus-on-managing-costs/article_0376fdda-f94e-11e6-80fe-87c4b330c9c3.html
http://www.iowafarmertoday.com/news/regional/fed-conference-highlights-downturn-decisions/article_1a389962-eeda-11e6-ab20-8f405756ad9a.html

Running the quarterly numbers from the Q4 2016 Ag Letter, land values need to increase by >1% in Q1 2017 in order for Q1 2017 land values to exceed those in Q1 2016. Reducing my forecast further, as in addition to previous factors:
-Real Estate loan interest rates have increased by full 25 bp to correspond with Fed hike (as expected)
-Credit conditions for farmers appear to continue to worsen, with close to 6% NPLs expected, and underwriting standards are tightening, decreasing availablity of credit
-Indications are that farm incomes and cash rents are decreasing in surrounding Fed Districts (http://www.thefencepost.com/news/federal-reserve-banks-farmland-values-down/) - thanks to @fburdine for that source Hard to see how the outlook for farmland valuations increasing next quarter is more positive than as of the Q3 2016 set of data.

Congress is considering a border adjustment tax. While, often linked to manufacturing exporters and retailing importers, such a change in the tax code we have wide ranging effects. One belief is that this will make the dollar stronger (thereby offsetting some of the retailers' concerns). If the $ is stronger, it could easily impact crop exports from the US. It seems that those willing to buy farmland (who are generally in it for a long term and that involves significant capital investment) will want a reasonable certainty of a positive profit-return. Until the tax question is in writing, there will be an overhang to farmland value.
Corn contracts improved and others holding.

Since the Q4 update has finally been published [1], the latest number is that Q4 was down 1% from last year. That's not great. Just by quickly eyeballing the numbers, their trajectories seems to be correlated, which means that the Q3 to Q4 change from -3 to -1 may carry forward into positive territory, increasing my estimate. 1: https://www.chicagofed.org/~/media/publications/agletter/2015-2019/february-2017-pdf.pdf

Recent release of Q4 numbers shows continued decrease, albeit at a lower rate. Difficult to see how the math works to show an increase in value as compared to the year ago period in Q1. Percentage change may increase, but I don't think values will get back to Q1 2016 levels in the quarter.
Dropping a lot on 4th Q results.
Consensus shift has surpassed my forecast, adjusting down accordingly.
Both real estate and food prices will almost certainly increase.

"Agricultural land values in the Seventh Federal Reserve
District suffered a third consecutive annual decrease, yet the
1 percent decrease for 2016 was smaller than the 3 percent
declines for the previous two years. “Good” farmland values
in the fourth quarter of 2016 were down 1 percent from the
third quarter, according to 192 survey respondents from
District banks. Nearly 60 percent of the survey respondents
expected farmland values to be stable during the January
through March period of 2017, while 40 percent expected
farmland values to decrease in their local areas." From Ag Letter February 2017
https://www.chicagofed.org/publications/agletter/index
https://www.chicagofed.org/publications/publication-listing?filter_series=1 ============ Edit: Only now I notice that the numbers for quarter-on-quarter growth are based on "good farmland" and the numbers for YoY-growth are based on "farmland".

For prices to be higher in Q1 2017 vs. Q1 2016, land values would need to increase by 5% or more based upon my review of the current trend data. In Q1 2016 prices were down 4%, in Q2 they were down an additional 1% and in Q3 they were down an additional 3%. We will need to see what the Q4 number is, but based upon the current trend and the recent commodity price environment, it is hard to see prices rebounding enough to claw back all of those losses.
My research suggests that farmland values are correlated with commodity prices, and the district's largest crop--corn--continues to see price declines.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

No shortage of these commodities, no indication that these commodities will become more valuable. No unusual weather events have occurred or are forecast. Chicken and Beef prices are not forecast to rise either. So unless this land can be converted into some new cash crop the chances of it increasing more than a 2-4% are pretty slim.  Carbon credits are a possibility but their current value is too low to impact the land prices.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

commodity PRICES HAVE BEGUN TO SLIP AND THE 2013-14 Cattle rally has faded. Only Colorado and Oklahoma - energy states saw increases in 2013-15 and this from Oil and Gas proceeds not traditional banking sources. Dropping to 10.

Unlikely to be resolved as "Yes".
* As of Q3 2016, it was still down 3%. In order to recover, it must recover that 3% and then enough to notice.
* These rates have been non-positive for more consecutive quarters than in the entire recorded history of the district, so the timing is unusual.
If Q4 numbers are positive, expect a strong update towards "Yes", but from here it seems unlikely.

Dropping as I think from figures we are currently at -1% for first six mths but can't work out how the figures work when I compare quarterly data to yearly. Anyone know how this works looking at results in spreadsheet from federal reserve bank of Chicago. Thanks
https://www.chicagofed.org/publications/agletter/index
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
General consensus appears to be too high.

Still following Dima-K. I can't find any evidence that his forecast of Oct. 28, 2016 has been outdated. See, for example, https://www.chicagofed.org/publications/agletter/index which reported, "Seventh District farmland values in the third quarter of 2016 were 3 percent lower than a year ago. Values for "good" agricultural land in the third quarter of 2016 were 1 percent lower than in the second quarter." Also, a shout out to  @Isaiah_Usher for his analysis based upon that Agletter and other sources data that he posted yesterday. Thank you for reengaging with Gjopen, and may we see more from you soon!

I discovered that 85,109 acres of farmland in the seventh district from 2014 to 2015 transitioned to premium higher priced farmland by getting certified organic. Comment: Recency bias could be the main reason for my lower than consensus forecast.  I wanted to find a reason why farmland in the 7th could rise which has not been discussed in the news, I think the rate of change to organic farmland may be it.  According to the USDA, "Organic sales account for over 4 percent of total U.S. food sales....and have experienced double digit growth year over year."  I am curious if organic can grow to say 10% of total U.S. food sales?  According to http://www.nasdaq.com/symbol/wfm/earnings-growth      Whole Foods has a great growth forecast for the next few years.  It must be acknowledged that there are approximately 150 million acres of farmland in the 7th district and about 544 thousand acres of organic farmland.  I don't think 100 thousand acres of new organic farmland in 2016 would impact farm values much?  But an investor it might be worthwhile to investigate transitioning farmland to premium organic farmland? https://www.ers.usda.gov/topics/natural-resources-environment/organic-agriculture.aspx https://www.nass.usda.gov/Surveys/Guide_to_NASS_Surveys/Organic_Production/Organic_Certifiers/2016/USDA_Accredited_Certifying_Agent_Certified_Organic_Data_2014_2015.pdf
Protectionist government stance should help land values. Stronger dollar may mitigate that effect, however.

Currently, land values would need to increase by c. 1% from Q3 2016 levels to reach Q1 2016 levels. From the November 2016 AgLetter (https://www.chicagofed.org/publications/agletter/2015-2019/november-2016)
"Moreover, according to the 208 agricultural bankers who responded to the October 1 survey, District farmland values decreased 1 percent in the third quarter of 2016 from the second quarter. A majority of the survey respondents saw the downward trend for agricultural land values continuing into the fourth quarter of 2016: 58 percent of the responding bankers anticipated a decrease in farmland values in the final quarter of 2016, while less than 1 percent anticipated an increase." From the data back to the 60s, c. 75% of quarters are positive percentage change and c. 25% are flat or negative. Valuation fundamentals continue to deteriorate: Yields up: "The USDA forecasted that the five District states’ harvest of corn for grain in 2016 would rise by 11 percent from 2015, establishing a new record. Likewise, soybean production for the five District states in 2016 was projected to break the record, set just last year—this year’s soybean harvest should exceed 2015’s by 9.2 percent, according to USDA projections." Prices overall down: "For the third quarter of 2016, prices for corn—the District’s largest cash crop—were down relative to the third quarter of the prior year. According to the USDA, corn prices averaged $3.34 per bushel in the third quarter of 2016, down 9.3 percent from the previous quarter and down 10 percent from a year ago. However, soybean prices, with an average of $9.85 per bushel in the third quarter of 2016, were up 2.0 percent from the previous quarter and up 3.0 percent from a year ago." From the Iowa State Farmland Value Survey (https://www.extension.iastate.edu/AGDM/wholefarm/html/c2-70.html)
"Although modest, the 5.9 percent decline represents a three-year streak where average Iowa farmland values have shown a decline, which is the first time this has happened since the 1980s. For a pessimist, there are plenty of legitimate reasons to worry:
-according to USDA, net farm income dropped another 17.2 percent to $66.9 billion in August 2016, and this represents the lowest since 2009 in both real and nominal terms.
-financial stress in the agricultural sector shows slow but steady increase, with continued declines in loan repayment rates and uptakes in farm real estate and working capital debt.
-while corn and soybean prices continue to fall short of production costs, livestock producers faced a tougher environment in 2016 with hog, cattle, and dairy prices all down by at least 30 percent compared to two years ago." Interest rates rose with the Fed hiking rates, sending the 10 year Treasury up to 2.30% - 2.60% as opposed to a Q3 range of c. 1.35% - 1.75%, increasing buyer discount rates and increasing the cost in interest rate for new loans (and affecting existing variable i.r. loans as well). These factors all point to a continued decline in farmland values. On the other hand, valuation and discounted cash flows are not necessarily the determinants of short term pricing for land. Supply of land coming to market is expected to be significantly below previous years. From the Iowa State survey: "ver half, (61 percent) of respondents reported lower sales in 2016 relative to 2015. On the other end of the spectrum, just 10 percent reported more sales, and 29 percent reported the same level of sales in 2016 relative to 2015." AND "Existing farmers represented 74 percent of the sales, with local farmers making of 72 percent and 2 percent to relocating farmers." Existing farm buyers might be happy to buy land that comes for sale that adjoins theirs at a higher cost then makes sense from a pure valuation point of view. Low supply of land for sale could A) prevent price discovery as land that has likely fallen in value on paper doesn't trade or B) there could be enough capital that wants to buy land due to choices that have already been made (funds raised, capital allocation by investors, targets by farm operators... who knows) that they pay a high price. However, given declining credit conditions, rising interest rates and weak repayment rates, it wouldn't take many forced sales to incrase the supply of land--by sellers who have to take a weak and/or market price. The data presented here is quite negative on the outlook for land values: https://durangoherald.com/articles/114965-more-farmers-are-having-trouble-making-loan-payments?wallit_nosession=1 So we have a 75% positive base rate or something like that and extremely bearish set of expert views. I don't have a mathematical basis for my probability but I think the chances of land values increasing over the next 2 quarters of data is low--but not as low as the "expert consensus"--and there is plenty of chances that short term movements in the data push Q1 2017 over the mark for Q1 2016.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Crop prices are broadly down or stable, and nothing is happening to goose up land sales in the short term.
Moving it up as there is a lot of movement toward 50% which makes me less certain. Will come back to this to check on updates I can find

Commercial real estate at all time highs, Residential real estate retracing all time highs, Stock record highs, Bonds just 30 year high (not all time) - the math for farmland is similar.  On contary, FPI (farm reit) has been a buyer of farmland in IL.  I would guess this was only done on weakness in perceived pricing.  I am lowering my level a touch.

The Fed 7 thinks we are not going to see improving land prices for at least another two q's,  the question been asked in the farmland are about the new administration priorities, so far DJT is not making happy the farmers, the lack of appointees to key agencies related to farming, is giving many farmers that he is ignoring farmers. I do not think that is correct, but farmers know  best.  Me thinks the lack of focus on farm it relates to the lack of knowledge of farm policy needs, and so far appointees for other posts seem to be in line with favoritism and oligarchic tendencies than field knowledge, and that will not work for the betterment of farming, with more impact in farming than in other agencies.

Ethanol subsidies have distorted farming practices in the upper Midwest, putting a greater emphasis on farming corn for several years straight. That has recently (in 2016) started to reverse and will continue to do so due to two factors: Trump, as well as a growing realization amongst farmers that the ethanol racket is unnatural and harmful to their livelihoods in the long run. Trump didn't run against ethanol, but there is nothing MORE political establishment than ethanol subsidies, so he endangers them.  Fewer ethanol subsidies equals fewer acres being cultivated equals lower demand for farmland equals lower farmland values.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

"Survey shows farmland values continuing in downward trend"

There is little evidence that land values will go anywhere but down in the short term, although since we are nearing the bottom of unemployment, higher wages and demand inflation might increase it later.

Everything I know or can find out about this suggests the GJP consensus is too high, and nobody seems to be able to explain what's driving it.  Perhaps some of our fellow forecasters are secretly buying up farmland in the 7th at wildly inflated prices, just so they can be right about this.  Seems unlikely, though.  Coming back down for a while.

Placing this at 50%. The data I've found indicates a fair chance that I should give this a lower probability, however I see the that GJ Consensus has driven the % up to 60%. Can anyone account to why this is the case? It feels higher than the reports I've found.
Reducing confidence substantially due to consensus (was at 5%). GJ must know something I've not made time to research.
Opec will have moderate success with production decreases which will sustain ethanol fuels production
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Consensus has risen a lot in last few weeks, not sure why. Increasing slightly to stay slightly above consensus.

Due to the significant number of trump voters in this demographic and their tendency to see themselves better off now that he is in office. Also, it seems like the urban areas of this region are expanding and becoming more stabilized.
What a difference an election makes.

Lowering my forecast because I found quarterly data for "good" farmland values in the 7th district. This question is asking us to estimate the cumulative change in value from 1Q2016 to 1Q2017. Using "good" farmland values as a proxy, the second and third quarters have had roughly neutral growth. So, we could reframe this question as, "what is the cumulative change over the next two quarters likely to be?". The average quarterly increase for farmland values in the 7th district is 1.8% and the standard deviation is 2.7%. Thus, in roughly 82% of cases, we should expect the cumulative change over the next two quarters to be greater than 0%.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Dropping slightly on start of beef trade war between US and Europe
https://www.rte.ie/news/2016/1222/840783-beef/

On one of several hands, folks often move into land investments when they think times are uncertain, and the prospect of another couple of Fed bumps might impel some purchasing early next year.  On another hand, farming is always chancy, considering both political and climate risk.  On yet another hand, if you can score some farmland close enough to a city and legally able to be rezoned, you might scoop it up for development.  Punchline:  Gonna be a close one, I think.
2017 will mark return of land inflation and many food commodity prices.
Arable land is dwindling and the cost of food is going up.
Interest rates are rising, significant risk of stock market correction, so perhaps prices unlikely to rise further in short term.

Large projected yields pressure grain prices.  Livestock sector under pressure.  By far most land is purchased by farmers so investor and alternative to stocks would have to be large to push prices up.  World politics supports strong dollar which depresses exports and tension with largest export customer China causes concern.  Land rents are down leading land prices lower.

Continued export demand will likely push prices.  Since Iowa will also hit ~100% renewable power from wind farms, it is likely that purchases of rights to place turbines will continue to increase, which itself will push farmland prices nominally higher.

This question has some ambiguous wording as it doesn't specify whether "farmland values" refers to average values, every state in the 7th district, or a weighted average of farmland values. Regardless, average farmland values in the 7th district go up roughly 87% of the time when measured on a YoY basis. Even if you extend the data back to the 1960s and look at appreciation in "good" farmland values only, values still go up roughly 83% of the time. I have not looked at possible explanatory variables, though.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
https://www.thebalance.com/how-the-dollar-impacts-commodity-prices-809294 Stronger dollar means lower commodity prices.
New President will bring positive growth.

The Fed raising interest rates will increase the value of the U.S. dollar and make U.S. exports more expensive causing grain prices to go down, and farmland values to go down.
Bean and Rice futures are down, likely making available additional acreage for Corn next spring. I think this supports a static trend.
Torn about this. Trend for past two years is downwards overall but mean reversion is possible.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Against the expectation I think Trump presidency will quickly lead to speculation to raising real-estate and land prices because of perceived inflation chance increase.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Not changing my number, but it occurs to me that always and everywhere, investors who are concerned about the medium-term economic future tend to move into either gold or land.  Also, there is a pretty good chance that the R Congress will seek to improve or secure their position in farm states by jacking up subsidies, improving the return on farmland.  Not likely either of these will kick in by this Q's deadline, but stay tuned.

Full disclosure: has no knowledge about farmland value or the 7th district before this. I ended up downloading the two spreadsheet for farmland price and credit condition, and do a Bayesian probability on two factors, farmland price year to year and loan repayment index.  I learn Bayesian from this site (http://www.kevinboone.net/bayes.html).  I end up try to answer this question, if repayment index is down, how likely will farmland value rise?  The data point used is from 1970Q1 to 2016Q3, and I simplify it by using "1" to mean rise and "0" to mean not rise.  Turns out during period, farmland rose 80% (150/187) of the time and repayment index fell 66% (124/187) of the time, of the 150 times that farmland went up, repayment index went down in 91 instances, or 61%.  So the equation is 91/150*80%/66%~74%.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Farm values have been declining in midwest for past couple of years.

with Trump protectionist rhetoric and threats to renege on US treaties, I think there is very high risk that we lose chunk of export market in coming years. That will likely be built into values in Q1 of 2017. Also, solar and gas will put downward pressure on ethanol (corn).
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Farmland value tracks closely the value of the crops (in this case corn). Corn prices have been declining steadily through the year and it is unlikely that they will change enough to positively influence the value of the farmland.
Overshooting consensus now that I have a slightly better understanding of the variables, and since I think my original assessment was justifiable. Went from less than 50-50 to 1 out of 5.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

We import corn cheaply from Brazil and export corn to China. The strong populist movements seem to hate China and trade, (see Trump, Sanders). Whether Clinton gets elected or not, the fact that we are subsidizing these industries and that the trade policies that generally benefit farmers are under attack, any quarrels with China and the world in general will depress the U.S.'s ability to compete in the global market. The damage has probably already been done since Trump's message resonates so well with red farming states. So it's not Trump that is the cause, but a reflection of frustration with farming in these areas. Add to that a little climate volatility, which is beginning to be accepted as a result of climate change, and the result could be difficulties farming due to weather events, and an inability to sell corn and soybean at better prices than last year. Also, the Brazil Real was cheaper last year (which would factor into the opposite conclusion) but lower in general, and China has been importing less.

I work in Ag business most of the year and here are some elements of farming/ farm real estate values that I believe are pertinent. The last two years of depressed crop prices + recent strong dollar have left American farmers with thin / red margins and limited capital to spend. But if they can afford it farmers are always interested in buying or leasing land that is close to their other farms. The depressed prices will cause many farmers to have to sell land and others to give up leases on farmland. Although this environment will lead to many leases changing hands and many farms being put up for sale, I think the lack of capital on hand and access to credit will cause more of those farms for sale that would normally sell to be leased instead of actually selling this year. Just a single line of thought but that's my initial take. Will have to look more at the numbers and how lease values factor into FMV...

Similar to comments made below (and backed by much more research).  Price trend is down, commodity prices very low with record crops predicted for next year, likely increase in interest rates in December will put pressure on already high debt levels.  While some areas will do better (see below) they probably won't offset the general trend. Midwest Farmland Values Mixed https://www.chicagofed.org/publications/agletter/index
According to the most recent AgLetter, Seventh District farmland values in the second quarter of 2016 were 1 percent lower than a year ago. However, values for “good” agricultural land in the second quarter of 2016 were 1 percent higher than in the first quarter.

Real income for farms has been falling. Commodity prices for farm products continue to see downward pressure. Additionally, farm debt as a percentage of income has been rising. Profit margins on farms have become razor thin and only farms of a significant size are able to survive without a secondary source of income. This will drive loan delinquency and consolidation of farm land, similar to what has been seen in previous periods where the farm debt to income ratio has increased.
Net income is decreasing since years. Additional land might be needed but the current owners will not spend more per square for New land like before.

Corn & Soybeans make up 60% of the commodity market across these states (with Dairy noteworthy of add'l ~20%) [1].  Both Soybeans and Corn have been trending down [2 & 3 respectively] and showing/projecting negative values in last quarter 2016 [4 & 5 respectively].  While its not clear what the "commodity trading prices-to-farmland value" relationship is, can't see how these are good indicators for farmland values going into Q1 '17.  The overall downward trend is what would cause me to think that farmland values won't be rising in next quarter. [1] http://data.ers.usda.gov/reports.aspx?ID=10633#P17eff3964e9c48fd80e15cec752eb385_10_586iT21R0x0
[2] http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/agricultural/grain-and-oilseed/corn.html
[3] http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/agricultural/grain-and-oilseed/soybean.html
[4] http://www.agweb.com/crops/corn/
[5] http://www.agweb.com/crops/soybeans/

According to the general news and GJP consensus.
Falling commodity prices and a likely interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve would be a headwind against increasing farmland values.
Question will be resolved by available money supply. Money will become more expensive and buyers will have fewer opportunities to buy land. I'm more inclined to the cost reduction.
The ag economy is deteriorating.  Big crops are helping farmers but not enough to keep farmland values at these elevated levels.

Commodity prices don't seem likely to help in the next few months.  The other driver of land prices in that region has been urban spreading which may also be slowing down, although not as much.  Something funky is going on in the southwestern part of the District--prices went up by 7% there, but not elsewhere in Illinois or across the River in Iowa.   Can't find a map that shows the precise correspondence of subdistricts to Illinois counties, but it looks like Adams upriver to Mercer, then east to maybe Bureau, then sort of west-southwest back to Adams but not including Sangamon.  Nothing about the farming situation has changed there, but it looks like that area includes Peoria, and also the newer commuting 'burbs of Springfield.  Expansion of those places may be bidding up land prices; similarly the creep of Chicago, Evanston, and Milwaukee 'burbs in Wisconsin, where farmland prices are going fairly strong.  (Yeah, people really do commute from Wisconsin to Chicago.) Since the District reports prices down only 1%, it may come down to how much developers are willing cough up to buy land which commuters will then have to cough up even more for, if they wish quieter surroundings and a much longer commute.   Full disclosure:  I have not worked in Illinois government for many years, although I still have lots of sources there and in some of the surrounding states in the Seventh.   Still, if I were you I wouldn't pay much attention to me.  My kid never did, and she turned out just fine.

In Illinois, the prices are down and are not expected to go up in the next few months:
http://farmdocdaily.illinois.edu/2015/10/2016-farmland-price-outlook.html
http://www.ispfmra.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/2016-Illinois-Farmland-Values-Lease-Trends.pdf The FRD Chicago survey indicates weakness in the farm land values for the district.
https://www.chicagofed.org/research/data/ag-conditions/index
Likely it will depend on the election of the president.  If Clinton wins, it will increase!

Multiple negative economic factors in agriculture sector such as elimination of federal price support programs leaves no safety net for ultra low commodity prices.   Conversion to wind farms is one alternative but not likely to reverse a probable multi year  trend in raw land prices by 2017 imo .

Following @pclinton tip on historical prices. "The last 50 years have been a consistent record of increasing farmland value with the exception of, 1982 – 86 where values dropped in 4 of the 5 years, and the last two years.
Stressed loans on farmlands have been on the rise the last two years and rental rates have been dropping for three years. Both of these suggest the farmland values will continue to decline. I will start with a conservative forecast of 35% and I will be watching commodity prices as farmland values seem to track them (corn, soybeans) somewhat closely. "
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/364001

The last 50 years have been a consistent record of increasing farmland value with the exception of, 1982 – 86 where values dropped in 4 of the 5 years, and the last two years. 
Stressed loans on farmlands have been on the rise the last two years and rental rates have been dropping for three years. Both of these suggest the farmland values will continue to decline. I will start with a conservative forecast of 35% and I will be watching commodity prices as farmland values seem to track them (corn, soybeans) somewhat closely.
Moved up on strength of @halito's comments.
Starting cautiously because single quarter vs single quarter previous year.  Even with general trend moving in a certain direction, possibility for corrections and outliers will matter.

We own a farm in this area.   So I hope the prices are higher even though we are not considering selling at anytime.  This year renewed rent agreements have continued to hold and offers to buy farmland are still strong.  All of these reasons would support level or higher land prices.
  The past few years have benefited from near perfect weather leading to large inventory of the most popular crops and the strong dollar has reduced the overseas demand for USA crops.  All of those reason would work against higher prices.
Considering both sides of the argument and my own contacts in the area I believe the increase will be very modest but not negative with respect to the land prices.
Prices have been declining for a while now. The Rabobank expects a further decline: http://1049maxcountry.com/agricultural/the-land-value-wave-dips/

overleverage, no more easy money, crop disinflation/deflation.  tepid sales from John Deere. abundant corn stockpiles. [crop yield * crop price] / land price = not good on a risk/reward basis. hope that i'm wrong cuz (small-time, mom/pop) farmers could use a break. [edit: worried that @slobodan is on the other side]
Going on fact they rose 1% in Q2, base rate probably a little above 50% as price s rise more often than fall.

Farmland values related to soybean, corn and livestock prices. Q2 2016, soy and corn prices were, on average (despite the June 2016 jump) broadly in line with Q2 2015. Current soybean prices are c. 10% above where they were in Q1 2016, while corn prices are c. 8% below. Livestock prices are c. 12% below where they were in Q1.  Taking these points together, I therefore feel that it is more likely than not that farmland values will be lower in Q1 2017 than they were in Q1 2016. So put the probability for this question (asking whether they will be higher) at 30%.
